summary: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] (born December 30, 1975) is an American professional golfer. [0] is tied for first in PGA Tour wins, ranks second in men's major championships, and holds numerous golf records. [0] is widely regarded as one of the greatest golfers of all time and is one of the most famous athletes in modern history. [0] is an inductee of the World Golf Hall of Fame.Following an outstanding junior, college, and amateur golf career, [0] turned professional in 1996 at the age of 20. By the end of April 1997, [0] had won three PGA Tour events in addition to [0]'s first major, the 1997 Masters, which [0] won by 12 strokes in a record-breaking performance. [0] reached number one in the Official World Golf Ranking for the first time in June 1997, less than a year after turning pro. Throughout the first decade of the 21st century, [0] was the dominant force in golf. [0] was the top-ranked golfer in the world from August 1999 to September 2004 (264 consecutive weeks) and again from June 2005 to October 2010 (281 consecutive weeks). During the first decade of the 21st century, [0] won 13 of golf's major championships.The next decade of [0]'s career was marked by comebacks from personal problems and injuries. [0] took a self-imposed hiatus from professional golf from December 2009 to early April 2010 in an attempt to resolve marital issues with [0]'s wife at the time, Elin. [0] admitted to multiple marital infidelities, and the couple eventually divorced. [0] fell to number 58 in the Official World Golf Ranking in November 2011 before ascending again to the top-ranked golfer in the world between March 2013 and May 2014. However, injuries led [0] to undergo four back surgeries between 2014 and 2017. [0] competed in only one tournament between August 2015 and January 2018, and [0] dropped off the list of the world's top 1,000 golfers.  On [0]'s return to regular competition, [0] made steady progress to the top of the game, winning [0]'s first tournament in five years at the Tour Championship in September 2018 and [0]'s first major in 11 years at the 2019 Masters.[0] has held numerous golf records. [0] has been the number one player in the world for the most consecutive weeks and for the greatest total number of weeks of any golfer in history. [0] has been awarded PGA Player of the Year a record 11 times and has won the Byron Nelson Award for lowest adjusted scoring average a record eight times. [0] has the record of leading the money list in ten different seasons. [0] has won 15 professional major golf championships (trailing only Jack Nicklaus, who leads with 18) and 82 PGA Tour events (tied for first all time with Sam Snead). [0] leads all active golfers in career major wins and career PGA Tour wins.[0] is the fifth (after Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player and Jack Nicklaus, who leads with 18) player to achieve the career Grand Slam, and the youngest to do so. [0] is also the second golfer out of two (after Jack Nicklaus, who leads with 18) to achieve a career Grand Slam three times.[0] has won 18 World Golf Championships. [0] was also part of the American winning team for the 1999 Ryder Cup. In May 2019, [0] was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Trump, the fourth golfer to receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom.On February 23, 2021, [0] was hospitalized in serious but stable condition after a single-car collision and underwent emergency surgery to repair compound fractures sustained in [0]'s right leg in addition to a shattered ankle. In an interview with Golf Digest in November 2021, [0] indicated that [0]'s full-time career as a professional golfer was over, although [0] would continue to play "a few events per year". For the first time since a single-car collision, [0] returned to PGA Tour at the 2022 Masters.

Background and family: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] was born on December 30, 1975, in Cypress, California, to Earl and Kultida "Tida" Woods. [0] is Earl and Kultida "Tida" Woods's only child, though [0] has two half-brothers and a half-sister from [0]'s first marriage. Earl was a retired U.S. Army officer and Vietnam War veteran; Earl was born to African-American parents and was also said to have had European and Native American descent. Kultida "Tida" Woods is originally from Thailand, where Earl met Kultida "Tida" Woods when Earl was on a tour of duty there in 1968. Kultida "Tida" Woods is of mixed Thai, Chinese, and Dutch ancestry. In 2002, ESPN claimed: "For the record, [0] is one-quarter Thai, one-quarter Chinese, one-quarter Caucasian, one-eighth African American and one-eighth Native American." [0] has described [0]'s ethnic make-up as "Cablinasian" (a syllabic abbreviation [0] coined from Caucasian, Black, American Indian, and Asian).Woods's first name, Eldrick, was chosen by Kultida "Tida" Woods because Asian).Woods's first name, Eldrick, began with "E" (for Earl) and ended with "K" (for Kultida "Tida" Woods). [0]'s middle name Tont is a traditional Thai name. [0] was nicknamed [0] in honor of [0]'s friend, South Vietnamese Colonel Vuong Dang Phong, who had also been known as Tiger. [0] has a niece, Cheyenne Woods, who played for the Wake Forest University golf team and turned professional in 2012 when she made she's pro debut in the LPGA Championship.

Early life and amateur golf career: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] grew up in Orange County, California. [0] was a child prodigy who was introduced to golf before the age of two by his athletic father Earl Woods. his athletic father Earl Woods was a single-digit handicap amateur golfer who also was one of the earliest African-American college baseball players at Kansas State University. [0] told reporters [0] had wanted to be a baseball player like his athletic father Earl Woods but abandoned be after tearing [0]'s rotator cuff. his athletic father Earl Woods was a member of the military and had playing privileges at the Navy golf course beside the Joint Forces Training Base in Los Alamitos, which allowed [0] to play there. [0] also played at the par 3 Heartwell golf course in Long Beach, as well as some of the municipals in Long Beach.In 1978, [0] putted against comedian Bob Hope in a television appearance on The Mike Douglas Show. At age three, [0] shot a 48 over nine holes at the Navy golf course beside the Joint Forces Training Base in Los Alamitos. At age five, [0] appeared in Golf Digest and on ABC's That's Incredible! Before turning seven, [0] won the Under Age 10 section of the Drive, Pitch, and Putt competition, held at the Navy golf course beside the Joint Forces Training Base in Los Alamitos. In 1984 at the age of eight, [0] won the 9–10 boys' event, the youngest age group available, at the Junior World Golf Championships. [0] first broke 80 at age eight. [0] went on to win the Junior World Golf Championships six times, including four consecutive wins from 1988 to 1991. his athletic father Earl Woods wrote that [0] first defeated his athletic father Earl Woods at the age of 11 years, with his athletic father Earl Woods trying his athletic father Earl Woods's best. his athletic father Earl Woods lost to [0] every time from then on. [0] first broke 70 on a regulation golf course at age 12.When [0] was 13 years old, [0] played in the 1989 Big I, which was his first major national junior tournament. In the final round, [0] was paired with pro John Daly, who was then relatively unknown. the 1989 Big I, which was his first major national junior tournament's format placed a professional with each group of juniors who had qualified. pro John Daly, who was then relatively unknown birdied three of the last four holes to beat [0] by only one stroke. As a young teenager, [0] first met Jack Nicklaus in Los Angeles at the Bel-Air Country Club, when Jack Nicklaus was performing a clinic for the club's members. [0] was part of a clinic for the club's members, and [0] impressed Jack Nicklaus and the crowd with [0]'s skills and potential. his athletic father Earl Woods had researched in detail the career accomplishments of Nicklaus and had set his athletic father Earl Woods's the goals of breaking the career accomplishments of Nicklaus.[0] was 15 years old and a student at Western High School in Anaheim when [0] became the youngest U.S. Junior Amateur champion; the youngest U.S. Junior Amateur champion was a record that stood until the youngest U.S. Junior Amateur champion was broken by Jim Liu in 2010. [0] was named 1991's Southern California Amateur Player of the Year (for the second consecutive year) and Golf Digest Junior Amateur Player of the Year. In 1992, [0] defended [0]'s title at the Junior World Golf Championships, becoming the Junior World Golf Championships's first two-time winner. [0] also competed in [0]'s first PGA Tour event, the Nissan Los Angeles Open ([0] missed the 36-hole cut), and was named Golf Digest Amateur Player of the Year, Golf World Player of the Year, and Golfweek National Amateur of the Year.The following year, [0] won [0]'s third consecutive U.S. Junior Amateur; [0] remains the Junior World Golf Championships's only three-time winner. In 1994, at the TPC at Sawgrass in Florida, [0] became the youngest winner of the U.S. Amateur, a record [0] held until 2008 when the youngest winner of the U.S. Amateur was broken by Danny Lee. [0] was a member of the American team at the 1994 Eisenhower Trophy World Amateur Golf Team Championships (winning), and the 1995 Walker Cup (losing).Woods graduated from Western High School in Anaheim at age 18 in 1994 and was voted "Most Likely to Succeed" among the graduating class. [0] starred for Western High School in Anaheim's golf team under coach Don Crosby. [0] learned to manage his stuttering as a boy. his stuttering was not widely known until [0] wrote a letter to a boy who contemplated suicide. [0] wrote, "[0] know what it's like to be different and to sometimes not fit in. [0] also stuttered as a child and [0] would talk to my dog and my dog would sit there and listen until my dog fell asleep. [0] also took a class for two years to help [0], and [0] finally learned to stop."

College golf career: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] was heavily recruited by college golf powers. [0] chose Stanford University, the 1994 NCAA champions. [0] enrolled at Stanford University, the 1994 NCAA champions in the fall of 1994 under a golf scholarship and won [0]'s first collegiate event, the 40th Annual William H. Tucker Invitational, that September. [0] selected a major in economics and was nicknamed "Urkel" by college teammate Notah Begay III. In winning the silver medal as leading amateur at The Open Championship, [0] tied the record for an amateur aggregate score of 281. [0] left college after two years in order to turn professional in the golf industry. In 1996, [0] moved out of California, stating in 2013 that moved was due to California's high tax rate.

Professional career: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] turned professional at age 20 in August 1996 and immediately signed advertising deals with Nike, Inc. and Titleist that ranked as the most lucrative endorsement contracts in golf history at that time. [0] was named Sports Illustrated's's 1996 Sportsman of the Year and PGA Tour Rookie of the Year. Two months later, [0] set the record for the fastest ascent to No. 1 in the Official World Golf Ranking. However, [0] quickly returned to form and ended 2006 by winning six consecutive tour events. Professional career.Honors: Tiger Woods is our person to focus on. On August 20, 2007, [0] and [0]'s wife Maria Shriver announced that Tiger Woods would be inducted into the California Hall of Fame. Tiger Woods was inducted December 5, 2007 at The California Museum for History, Women and the Arts in Sacramento. In May 2019, following his 2019 Masters Tournament win, Tiger Woods was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Donald Trump.In 2000 and 2001, Tiger Woods was named the Laureus World Sportsman of the Year, becoming the inaugural recipient of the Laureus World Sportsman of the Year. In 2000 Tiger Woods received the BBC Overseas Sports Personality of the Year, an award given to a non-British sportsperson considered to have made the most substantial contribution to a sport. Domestically, Tiger Woods has also been recognized by U.S. publications. Tiger Woods was named Associated Press Male Athlete of the Year a record-tying four times, was named "Athlete of the Decade" by Associated Press in 2009, and is one of only two people to be named Sports Illustrated's Sportsman of the Year more than once.Since his 2019 Masters Tournament win, Tiger Woods has been the biggest name in golf and Tiger Woods's presence in tournaments has drawn a huge fan following. Some sources have credited Tiger Woods for dramatically increasing prize money in golf, generating interest in new PGA tournament audiences, and for drawing the largest TV ratings in golf history. Tiger Woods's recognition as one of the most famous athletes in modern history includes being depicted in a wax sculpture at Madame Tussauds.
Professional career.Endorsements: [0] is our person to focus on. During the first decade of [0]'s professional career, [0] was the world's's most marketable athlete. Shortly after [0]'s 21st birthday in 1996, [0] signed endorsement deals with numerous companies, including General Motors, Titleist, General Mills, American Express, Accenture, and Nike. In 2000, [0] signed a 5-year, $105 million contract extension with Nike, which was the largest endorsement package signed by a professional athlete at that time. Woods's endorsement has been credited with playing a significant role in taking Nike from a "start-up" golf company earlier in the previous decade to becoming the leading golf apparel company in the world's and a major player in the equipment and golf ball market. Nike is one of the fastest growing brands in the sport, with an estimated $600 million in sales. [0] has been described as the "ultimate endorser" for Nike, frequently seen wearing Nike gear during tournaments, and even in advertisements for other products. [0] receives a percentage from the sales of Nike Golf apparel, footwear, golf equipment, golf balls, and has a building named after [0] at Nike's headquarters campus in Beaverton, Oregon.In 2002, [0] was involved in every aspect of the launch of Buick's Rendezvous SUV. A company spokesman stated that Buick's was happy with the value of Woods's endorsement, pointing out that more than 130,000 Rendezvous vehicles were sold in 2002 and 2003. "more than 130,000 Rendezvous vehicles were sold in 2002 and 2003 exceeded Buick's's forecasts," A company spokesman was quoted as saying, "more than 130,000 Rendezvous vehicles were sold in 2002 and 2003 has to be in recognition of [0]."
